Thus, the veils remain drawn, and the matter cannot be otherwise. Look at His saying regarding the lifting of the veils, where He mentioned the burning of the splendors of the Face (سبحات الوجه) of whatever His sight perceives of His creation. Yet, He described Himself as being seen by creation without them being burned. This indicates that the veils are not lifted during the vision (الرؤية). The vision must necessarily be veiled (حجابية). The pronoun in "His sight" (بصره) refers back to "whatever" (ما), and "whatever" here is the very essence of His creation. It is as if He is saying, in the estimation of the speech, "whatever the sight of His creation perceives." For there is no doubt that He perceives us today with His sight, and the splendors of His Face are present. If the veils were the essence of creation, they would not be lifted. If they were created things, the splendors would burn them, for they are perceived by His sight without a veil. If the veils were burned, we would be burned and would not exist, yet we undoubtedly exist. Thus, the veils are drawn. If people understood the meaning of this report, they would know themselves, and if they knew themselves, they would know the Real, and if they knew the Real, they would be satisfied with Him and would look only at Him, not at the dominion of the heavens and the earth. For when the matter is unveiled to them, they know that He is the very dominion of the heavens and the earth, just as Al-Tirmidhi al-Hakim knew, who, upon this Divine Unveiling (الكشف الإلهي), named Him the King of the Kingdom (ملك الملك).

The matter is circular and is not known,
And the affair is ruled and does not rule.

There is none but Allah, and no other,
And there is none but His established Being.

He is the one who knows at one time, just as
He is ignorant at another time and is not known.

### A Section: [Were it not for Light, nothing would be perceived, neither known nor sensed]

Know—may Allah support you—that the matter implies that were it not for Light (النور), nothing would be perceived, neither known (معلوم) nor sensed (محسوس) nor imagined (متحيل) at all. The names assigned to the faculties (القوى) differ concerning Light. For the common people, they are names for the faculties, but for the Gnostics (العارفين), they are names for the Light by which perception occurs. When sounds are perceived, that Light is called hearing. When sights are perceived, that Light is called sight. When tangibles are perceived, that means of perception is called touch. And similarly for the imaginables. It is the faculty of touch (القوة اللامسة), nothing else, and the faculty of smell, taste, imagination, memory, intellect, thought, and formation (المصورة). Everything by which perception occurs is nothing but Light. As for the perceived objects (المدركات), were they not inherently prepared to accept the perception of the perceiver, they would not be perceived. They have a manifestation (ظهور) toward the perceiver, and then perception relates to them. Manifestation is Light. Therefore, every perceived object must have a relation (نسبة) to Light, by which it is prepared to be perceived. Every known thing (معلوم) has a relation to the Real (الحق), and the Real is the Light. Thus, every known thing has a relation to Light. By Light, the Impossible (المحال) is perceived. Were it not for the manifestation of the Impossible and its acceptance of what it is in itself, the perceiver would not perceive what it perceives. For this reason, [the ruling of Light] extends to every division of the intellect, just as the ruling of necessity (الوجوب) also extends to these divisions. We say: it is impossible (محال) for the Necessary Existent by Essence (الواجب الوجود بالذات) to accept non-existence. It is impossible for the Possible (الممكن) to accept essential existence. It is impossible for the Impossible (المحال) to accept possibility (الإمكان). Similarly, concerning necessity (الوجوب), we say: it is necessary (واجب) for the Possible to have an equal relation to non-existence and existence. It is necessary for the Impossible not to be described by possibility. We do not apply the like of this to possibility (الإمكان). You do not say: it is possible for the Impossible to be such-and-such, or possible for the Necessary to be such-and-such, thereby making the Possible subject to the ruling of the Necessary or the Impossible. The Necessary and the Impossible do not fall under the ruling of the Possible. For this reason, it is not permissible to say of the Necessary that it is possible for something to be done to it or not done. Rather, what is said and is correct to say is concerning the Possible: that it is possible for something to be done to it or not done. This is an issue that many people have overlooked. You have learned that there is no known thing, whether impossible or otherwise, that does not have a relation to Light. Were it not for that Light to which it has a relation, it would not be valid to be known. There is no known thing but Allah. In reality, no one knows what he is saying or how to relate matters, despite his understanding them, and expressions fall short of encompassing them fully. Indeed, Allah is All-Knowing of everything (عليم بكل شي‏ء) from the perspective of the Light that thing possesses, by which it becomes known. Non-existence and the Impossible are known.

There is nothing other than the thing, since there is no other,
So, from its being Light, Knowledge encompasses it.

If you verify what we have indicated, you will stand upon the realities of the known things (المعلومات)—how they are in themselves, in their characterization by existence, non-existence, or neither existence nor non-existence, or negation or affirmation.

This is the strange knowledge, and if you are
One of its companions, you are the stranger, yet you do not know.

Just as there is one who knows his strangeness, and this one
Is more complete in existence in contemplating the matter.

Glory be to Him who revives the heart with His Light,
And His Light is sometimes by thought and sometimes by remembrance.

As for the Light that is not perceived, which is His saying (peace and blessings be upon him), "Light (نوراني); how could I see Him?"—that is due to the Light of perception (نور الإدراك) being subsumed within it. It did not perceive it because it is not alien to it; it is like the part returning to its whole. The name 'whole' (الكل) is not valid for it unless it encompasses its parts. The part is thus subsumed within the whole, and the whole is not other than its parts. The whole perceives its parts, part by part, but the part does not perceive the whole. For this reason, the Real knows the particulars (الجزئيات), but the particulars do not know Him. If the part knows the whole, it knows only the essence of its own particularity, for it knows a whole in itself, for itself. It may not know that it is a part of a whole. For this reason, people differ in knowledge. The one who knows a thing is he for whom no aspect of that known thing remains unknown to him; otherwise, he has known only what he has known of it. As for the Light that is perceived and by which other things are perceived, it is a light equivalent to the Light of perception. It accompanies it but is not subsumed within it. Thus, it perceives it and perceives by it what it unveils to it. And what is unveiled to it is unveiled only by the two lights: the Light of perception and the Light of the perceived object. Were it not for the existence of the Light of perception, things would not manifest. Nothing manifests by the Light of the perceived object without the Light of perception. Some things may manifest to the Light of perception, but by the Light of the perceived object, even if the perceiver does not perceive it by that light, as we said regarding the relation of every known thing to the Light, without which it would not be known. Sight perceives darkness itself but does not perceive anything else by it, if the perception is specifically by sight.

### A Section: As for conceptual darknesses

As for conceptual darknesses (الظلم المعنوية), such as the darkness of ignorance (ظلمة الجهل), it is perceived by the knowledgeable person (العالم), but if it resides in the ignorant person (الجاهل), he does not perceive it, for if he perceived it, he would be knowledgeable. All darknesses other than the darkness of ignorance are perceived entirely. Then, know that if ignorance is the negation of knowledge concerning a locus regarding a certain matter, then everything other than Allah is ignorant—meaning the darkness of ignorance is necessary for it—because it does not possess comprehensive knowledge of all known things. For this reason, Allah commanded His Messenger (peace and blessings be upon him) to seek an increase in knowledge, saying to him, <<وَقُلْ رَبِّ زِدْنِي عِلْمًا>> (And say, 'My Lord, increase me in knowledge') [Q. 20:114]. If the darkness of ignorance is defined as believing a thing to be contrary to what it is, then the People of Allah (أهل الله) have been removed from this darkness, for they do not believe in a matter that is, in itself, contrary to what they believe. And He said, <<وَعَلَّمَ آدَمَ الْأَسْمَاءَ كُلَّهَا>> (And He taught Adam all the names) [Q. 2:31]. He did not mention the realities of the named things (حقائق المسميات). So, he knew some and did not know others. The named things are His saying, "these" (هؤلاء), which are referred to in His saying, <<أَنْبِئُونِي بِأَسْمَاءِ هَؤُلَاءِ إِنْ كُنْتُمْ صَادِقِينَ>> (Inform Me of the names of these, if you are truthful) [Q. 2:31]. By the names here, He meant the Divine Names (الأسماء الإلهية) upon which those referred to by "these" relied for their existence and rulings, as a rebuke to the angels and an affirmation. He is saying: Did you glorify Me with these Names, or sanctify Me with them, when they said, <<وَنَحْنُ نُسَبِّحُ بِحَمْدِكَ وَنُقَدِّسُ لَكَ>> (While we declare Your praise and sanctify You)? [Q. 2:30]. They purified themselves and criticized Allah's vicegerent (خليفة الله) on His earth, which they should not have done. But this is so you may know that no one in the world has estimated Allah with His true measure, for I do not know of the angels having the knowledge of Allah and the reverence due to His Majesty. Yet, they said, <<أَتَجْعَلُ فِيهَا مَنْ يُفْسِدُ فِيهَا>> (Will You place upon it one who causes corruption therein?) [Q. 2:30]. This interrogative particle (أ) here should only come from the superior concerning the inferior, like His saying, <<أَأَنْتَ قُلْتَ لِلنَّاسِ اتَّخِذُونِي وَأُمِّي إِلَهَيْنِ مِنْ دُونِ اللَّهِ>> (Did you say to the people, 'Take me and my mother as two gods besides Allah'?) [Q. 5:116]. But the angels' saying, <<أَتَجْعَلُ فِيهَا مَنْ يُفْسِدُ فِيهَا>> is even stronger than this.

When they saw the side of the left, but did not see
From Him the right of the White Hand.

As for the darkness of distance (ظلمة البعد) in His saying, <<يَا أَيُّهَا النَّاسُ>> (O mankind) and <<يَا أَيُّهَا الَّذِينَ آمَنُوا>> (O you who have believed), and in such sayings as <<تُوبُوا إِلَى اللَّهِ جَمِيعًا أَيُّهَا الْمُؤْمِنُونَ>> (Turn to Allah in repentance, all of you, O believers) [Q. 24:31] and the like—this stems from the ruling of the Divine Names (الأسماء الإلهية). For every time, there is a Divine Name whose ruling applies to a specific essence (عين) among the essences of the world. If the Name's ruling contradicts the ruling of what the obligated person (المكلف) is commanded or forbidden, then the Divine Name that grants them conformity to what Allah commanded or forbade is distant from them. So, He calls out to them to return to Him and listen to His call, so that His ruling may apply to them. Whether the call is from near or far, due to the lack of conformity to what Allah commanded, they are necessarily distant. Do you not see that a gesture (الإشارة) occurs when the gesturer and the one gestured to are close, if there is a third person present whom the speaker or the recipient does not want to know what the speaker intends to convey to his companion? He gestures to him without the third person knowing. Among the people [of Sufism], the gesture is considered a call at the height of distance. They also say, "The one furthest from Allah is the one who gestures to Him the most." The reason for this is that it indicates ignorance of Allah (الجهل بالله تعالى). In that state, there is no difference between him and one whom the voice does not reach but the gesture does. All of this is a darkness that has veiled the third person from knowing what is between the two. This is the darkness of calling and gesturing. Pay attention, for Allah has alerted some of His servants and guided them to matters through speech that only those intended understand, which is the symbol (الرمز). He said, <<أَلَّا تُكَلِّمَ النَّاسَ ثَلَاثَةَ أَيَّامٍ إِلَّا رَمْزًا>> (That you will not speak to the people for three nights, except by sign) [Q. 19:10]. As for the darkness of equating two matters (ظلمة التسوية بين الأمرين), it is called darkness because true equality (التسوية المحققة)—meaning identity in all aspects, not just some or most—is impossible between two matters. He said, <<سَوَاءٌ عَلَيْهِمْ أَأَنْذَرْتَهُمْ أَمْ لَمْ تُنْذِرْهُمْ>> (It is the same for them whether you warn them or do not warn them) [Q. 36:10], because they had said, <<سَوَاءٌ عَلَيْنَا أَوَعَظْتَ أَمْ لَمْ تَكُنْ مِنَ الْوَاعِظِينَ>> (It is the same for us whether you advise or are not among the advisers) [Q. 26:136]. Thus, Allah recounted their state to His Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) and informed him that their condition was as they described themselves. This darkness may be the darkness of ignorance, or it may be the darkness of denial due to a passion (هوى) residing within them, which is one of the severest darknesses. However, all of these are merely magical twilight shadows (سدف سحرية) when compared and related to the darkness of ignorance (ظلمة الجهل) which is the complete negation of knowledge from the locus, which is His saying concerning it: "what no eye has seen, nor ear heard, nor has it occurred to the heart of man."

He negated knowledge and the paths leading to the knowledge of that thing. This is the severest darkness in the world to me. For believing a thing to be contrary to what it is means that the thing is known, but its reality is not known—meaning it is known in general that its name is such-and-such, but then one believes about it what is not true of it. Thus, one has believed in *something*. Its darkness is less than the darkness of negating knowledge entirely from the locus, as He said concerning their likes, <<وَبَدَا لَهُمْ مِنَ اللَّهِ مَا لَمْ يَكُونُوا يَحْتَسِبُونَ>> (And there will appear to them from Allah that which they had not anticipated) [Q. 39:47]. This is common among the wretched and the fortunate. For the fortunate, it applies to one who dies without repentance, believing in the execution of the threat (الوعيد), yet is forgiven. The ruling was thus for the Divine Will (المشيئة), which preceded with their happiness. It then became clear to them that they had believed concerning that matter contrary to what the matter truly was. For what the matter truly was, was choice (الاختيار), while what they had concluded was the absence of choice. Such a case is called the darkness of ambiguity (ظلمة الشبهة).

O sons of Zawra, what is between me and you?
I belong to one who is not wronged.

So if I say 'Is it not?' (ألا), say 'Yes, indeed' (بلى),
And if I say 'Is it?' (هل), say 'Yes' (نعم).

The matter I have brought
Is an existent matter possessing the attribute of pre-eternity.

One in its essence, we have no
Pre-eternity in what manifests therein.

And that which I bring forth is brought forth to me,
Between two matters: existence and non-existence.

To us belong the Lights from Him if He manifests,
And to Him belong the hidden places of Darkness from us.

They are the veils of Allah that we may perceive Him,
And by them stand the indications of suspicion.

Then within them are signs of guidance,
For His Theophany (تجليه): knowledges and wisdoms.

The nature of the world has divided them,
And what the Real is upon, He has judged.

Just as we are by Him, so is He by us,
Transformations like fire on a banner.

Whenever I spoke, His form appeared
Around the form, in quality and quantity.

So I transformed, and the state
Of the matter became obscure to us, and it was obscured.

Would that I knew: Is the matter as
It appeared, or other than it? Speak, O Judge!

He said: By Allah, I am like you,
Perplexed, having no pre-eternity in knowledge.

### [Indeed, the keys of the Unseen are with Allah]

Know—may Allah support you—that when Allah brought man forth from the darkness of the Unseen (ظلمة الغيب) in which he was, which is the first key of the keys of the Unseen (مفاتيح الغيب) <<لَا يَعْلَمُهَا إِلَّا هُوَ>> (which none knows but He) [Q. 6:59], He singled Himself out by the knowledge of them and negated the knowledge of them from everything other than Himself. He established you in this verse and informed you that you are not He, for if you were He, as you claim, you would know the keys of the Unseen by your Essence (بذاتك), and not only through a station (موقف). Thus, you are not the essence of the station. All Possibles (الممكنات)—and by 'all' I mean distinguishing them from the Impossible and the Necessary, not that their essences are encompassed by the totality, which is impossible—are in the darkness of the Unseen. No state of existence is known for them. For every Possible among them, there is a key, and that key is known only to Allah. There is no creator (موجد) but Allah; He is the Creator of everything (خالق كل شي‏ء), meaning its Existent-Maker (موجده). The first key by which He opened was the key of the Unseen of the Perfect Human (الإنسان الكامل), who is the Shadow of Allah (ظل الله) in everything other than Allah. He manifested him from the Breath of the Merciful (النفس الرحماني) which issues from the heart of the Quran, Surah Ya Sin. This is a truncated call (نداء مرخم), meaning "O Master" (يا سيد), truncated just as one says *Yā Abā Har* intending *Yā Abā Hurayrah*. He established his mastery (السيادة) with this name and made it truncated to signify the submission (التسليم) required by Mercy and the cutting off of what remained of him in the Unseen (الغيب) that could not emerge. His form in the Unseen is the form of the shadow in the person from whom the shadow extends. Do you not see that when a person's shadow extends onto the ground, he also has a shadow within the essence of the person that corresponds to the extended shadow? That shadow subsisting in the essence of the person corresponding to the extended shadow is the matter that remained of the human, who is the extended Shadow of Allah (ظل الله الممدود) in the Unseen, which can never emerge. That is the inner aspect of the extended shadow, and the extended shadow is the outer aspect. The outer aspect of man is what extended from man and manifested, and his inner aspect is what never left the Unseen. Thus, the inner aspect of man is never known. The relation of his outer aspect to his inner aspect is continuous and never leaves him for the blink of an eye; its separation is impossible. He is outwardly Unseen and inwardly manifest. He has the ruling of what manifested from him in movement and rest. If he moves, he moves by the Real; if he rests, he rests by the Real. He is upon the form of the Existent-Maker (موجده). The other Possibles do not possess this perfection. There is no Unseen more perfect than the Unseen of Man. When Allah brought him forth into Existence, He brought him forth upon rectitude (الاستقامة) and granted him Mercy. By it, He opened the locked doors of matters, high and low. He supported the likes (الأمثال) with His Essence and supported the non-likes (غير الأمثال) with His likeness. By His likeness, bodies (الأجسام) appeared, and by His other likeness, spirits (الأرواح) appeared. They are to him like the right and the left, due to the deficiency of bodies compared to spirits, like the deficiency of the left compared to the right. The one with absolute hands is the likeness, and its example is in the margin. He only brought the world into existence, as we mentioned, through a Divine movement (حركة إلهية), which is the movement of the key during the opening. Although the Possibles are endless, they are, in one respect, confined to ten things, which are the Ten Categories (المقولات العشرة). We have mentioned them previously in this book. Let us explain their levels here, specifically concerning this chapter, which we have not mentioned before.

### [Among the Divine Names is The Inner]

Know that Allah possesses The Inner (الباطن) among the Divine Names in the Presence of the Unseen (حضرة الغيب) that belongs to Him. We never know a ruling of His that manifests in man without manifesting in other creatures, due to man's comprehensiveness (الجمعية) and his distinction by the universality of the Breath of the Merciful (النفس الرحماني). That ruling in the Unseen of the Real has permanence always, as long as The Inner is connected to The Outer (الظاهر) for the sake of the sustenance (الامداد) from the Creator to the created. If it were cut off from him, he would perish. For this reason, linguists made connection (الوصل) the basis of speech, and pause (الوقف) an accidental occurrence in speech due to the shortness of breath that the expelling force brings forth. If it continued, the speaker would perish. When [the speaker] fears perishing, the attracting force draws air from outside inward. The pause of the speaker for rest occurs between the end of the expelling force and the beginning of the attracting force. This is why we said it is accidental. In the Divine Breath (النفس الإلهي), from the perspective of its being the Breath of the Merciful, is what Allah afflicts His servant with of constriction (الضيق) and distress (الحرج), and then relieves him with expansion (السعة). Thus, a thing is countered by its opposite. When two opposites alternate upon a locus, there must be a state of astonishment (بهت) that arises in the locus. That astonishment is called the pause (وقفا) in the world of speech. This is one of the comprehensive words (جوامع الكلم), which is the collection of a word. The astonishment occurs between one word and the next because the breath in the two words is a single essence. Allah said, <<وَكَانَ اللَّهُ عَلِيمًا حَكِيمًا>> (And Allah is ever Knowing and Wise) [Q. 4:170]. If you pause, *Alīman* (Knowing) is what is in the Divine Unseen, and *Hakīman* (Wise) is His ruling in man, sustained by Allah. If He connects it with speech after it, Allah takes him back to Himself, <<قَبْضًا يَسِيرًا>> (a gentle taking) [Q. 4:170], and he returns to His Unseen, and His ruling does not manifest in man. This is one of the secrets of the Real, the ultimate expression of which is what we have mentioned.

### [The First Vicegerency of the Perfect Human Manifest in the Divine Form]

The Perfect Human (الإنسان الكامل) who manifests in the Divine Form (الصورة الإلهية) was not granted this perfection by Allah except to be a substitute (بدلا) for the Real. For this reason, He named him Caliph (خليفة). Those who follow him, who are his likes, are his successors (خلفاء له). The first one alone is the Caliph of the Real (خليفة الحق), and those of his likes who manifested from him in the world of bodies are the successors of this Caliph and substitutes for him in every matter that is valid for him. For this reason, the Ten Categories (المقولات العشرة), which cannot be increased beyond this number, are valid for him. This is the First Vicegerency (النيابة الأولى).

### [The Second Vicegerency is that man acts as deputy by his essence for half of the Form, from the perspective of its spirituality]

As for the Second Vicegerency (النيابة الثانية), it is that man acts as deputy by his essence for half of the Form, from the perspective of its spirituality (روحانيتها). For when Allah discloses Himself (تجلى) in the form of man, as reported, He manifests in its form, both sensually and conceptually. The specific deputyship here is the deputyship for the spirit (روح) of that Form in which the Theophany occurs. This only happens in the Presence of the Divine Acts (حضرة الأفعال الإلهية) that manifest in the world through man, from the perspective of his being the one who wills (مريد) to perform an act he intends to do immediately or in the future. An act only becomes past after its manifestation in the present. Man thus acts as deputy for Allah in all present acts that manifest through his hand. No one other than man has this deputyship. The angel, the animal, the mineral, and the plant—none of these have a will (إرادة) related to any matter. They are only concerned with the prostration (السجود) and praise (الثناء) upon which they were created. Their occupation is *with* Him, not *away* from Him. Man, however, has occupation both with Him and away from Him. The occupation away from Him is what is expressed as heedlessness (الغفلة) and forgetfulness (النسيان). The Real here is a circle, from the perspective of the Form combining the spiritual meaning and the visible aspect. In this deputyship, man is only a deputy for the acts related to the spirituality of that Form. The world of spirits (عالم الأرواح) is subtler than the world of bodies. Due to its subtlety, it quickly transforms into forms without the essence being corrupted. The world of bodies is not like that.

### [The Third Vicegerency in realizing the matter that subsists in the Possible]

Know that the Third Vicegerency (النيابة الثالثة) lies in realizing the matter that subsisted in the Possible (الممكن) until it brought it forth from Non-existence (العدم) to Existence (الوجود). This is a deputyship for the meaning that necessitated the Real to bring this specific Possible into existence, when He had not brought it into existence before, whether it was a spirit or a body. Know that the acts issuing from the one who wills (المريد) have, in their likenesses, a deputyship in the manifest realm for Allah in the issuance of the Possibles from Him. He is not a deputy for Him unless the one who appointed him as successor and deputy becomes his hearing, sight, hand, and all his faculties. If he is not characterized by this description, he is neither a deputy nor a Caliph. The Possibles, in their state of non-existence, are before the Real. He looks at them and distinguishes them from one another by the realities they possess in the thingness of their immutability (شيئية ثبوتها). He looks at them with the eye of His Beautiful Names (أسمائه الحسنى), such as The Knowing (العليم) and The Preserver (الحفيظ), who preserves their immutable thingness by the Light of His Existence, lest the Impossible (المحال) strip them of that thingness. For this reason, He extended Mercy upon them, by which He opened Existence. The order of the creation of the Possibles necessitates the precedence of some over others, and this is undeniable, for it is the reality. The entry into the thingness of Existence (شيئية الوجود) occurred in an ordered manner, contrary to their state in the thingness of immutability (شيئية الثبوت), for they are all unordered, because their immutability is described as being eternal (الأزل) for them, and eternity has no order, precedence, or subsequence. Since the Divine Names include the general, the more general, the specific, and the more specific, precedence, subsequence, and order are valid for the Divine Names. By this, the thingnesses of Existence accepted order. There is no time that passes you by here in which a specific Possible does not manifest, and then manifests in the second time, except that its remaining in the thingness of its immutability was determined (مرجح) in the time when the thingness of its existence did not subsist in it. For if it had not been determined, it would have existed in the time we said passed without it existing therein. Thus, the remaining of every Possible was determined in its state of non-existence, even though non-existence is eternal for it, just as its acceptance of the thingness of its existence is determined. This is one of the most astonishing subtleties of issues if you reflect upon it. The ruling of the Will (الإرادة) is dependent upon the ruling of Knowledge (العلم). For this reason, He said, <<إِذَا أَرَدْنَاهُ>> (When We intend it) [Q. 36:82], using the future tense adverb of time (إذا) in relating the Will. The Will is one essence. Its ruling thus shifted from determining the remaining of the Possible in the thingness of its immutability to its ruling determining its manifestation in the thingness of its existence. This is a Divine, Holy, transcendent movement (حركة إلهية قدسية منزهة) granted by the reality of possibility (حقيقة الإمكان), which is the reality of the Possible. When Allah created the Possible creature, characterized by Will and Power (الإرادة والقدرة) to manifest acts from him by the ruling of deputyship for Allah in the manifest matter, not in the inner matter—for He, glory be to Him, is in the inner aspect the Manifestor of the Possible in the thingness of its existence from behind the veil of the manifest, willing, powerful one, who is the creature possessing this attribute. He is the Hand of Allah (يد الله), willing by the Will of Allah. He acts by spiritual resolve (بالهمة), as in His saying, <<كُنْ>> (Be!), and He acts by direct engagement (بالمباشرة), like His creation of Adam with His two hands, and everything He attributed to the creation of His Hand. This is said concerning the Real with this relation, without direct engagement, while in the servant, it is direct engagement. If it occurs without a will for it, that is not our subject, nor do we discuss it. That belongs to Him, glory be to Him, manifesting it in that specific locus, like the movement of a trembling person, and everything that issues without will. Such a person is not a deputy possessing this attribute. The deputy is informed by Allah in his heart of what the Real intends to bring into existence of the Possibles. His being informed is of two types: sometimes it is through speculation and thought (نظر وفكر), so he acts as deputy by his speculation and thought for Allah, the Director and Detailer, from the perspective that <<يُدَبِّرُ الْأَمْرَ يُفَصِّلُ الْآيَاتِ>> (He arranges [all] matters and details the signs) [Q. 13:2]. And sometimes, it occurs to him spontaneously (بديهيا), what Allah casts into his inner being, just as Divine Knowledge grants Divine Will the relation to bringing something into existence without the ruling of the Name 'The Director, The Detailer.' This Possible then manifests through the hand of this creature who wills it. He is the deputy in both aspects: direction and spontaneity. This deputy has thus gained insight into the Presence of the Immutable Essences (أعيان الممكنات) in their thingness of immutability, within the deputy in the Presence of his Imagination (حضرة خياله). This is because Allah brought this Possible out of the thingness of its immutability into the thingness of its existence in the Presence of Imagination, so that a distinction occurs between Allah and the deputy in the manifestation of this essence whose existence is sought in the sensory world (عالم الحس). This essence is then characterized as sensible if it is a form, or if it is not a form that sight perceives, it is a meaning, and He clothes it in the form of expressions (العبارات) or the form of what indicates it, such as a hint or a gesture. That is its form by which it can manifest to the eye of the viewer, the listener, or whatever. The deputy, in reality, only brought forth by Will what he brought forth from an imaginary, conceptual, or intelligible existence into a sensory existence (وجود حسي) restricted by a specific form, or a verbal form, or whatever. Sight relates to this existence from the viewer if it is in the form of an essence, and if it is in the form of a word and its likes, it is perceived by hearing. Such existence and creation are attributed to the deputy, but the condition of Will and Choice (الإرادة والاختيار) is necessary in this. If he is devoid of them, he is not a deputy, even if that manifests from him and through him. Rather, that belongs to Allah. As for the existence of what cannot be expressed, the deputy has absolutely no involvement in it, for that is among the exclusive properties of the Real. So, understand what we have clarified for you, for it is from the core of Gnosis (لباب المعرفة).

### [As for the Fourth Vicegerency, it is his deputyship in what the Real established for him]

As for the Fourth Vicegerency (النيابة الرابعة), it is his deputyship in what the Real established for him, which, had it not been through him, would have been through Allah Himself. Know that when Allah willed to be known, He necessarily had to establish a proof (دليلا) for His knowledge. The proof must be equal to Him in the knowledge of Him, from the perspective of His being an existent matter, and must be knowledgeable of itself, from the perspective of its being described by an attribute called Knowledge (العلم), and knowledgeable of itself by seeing itself, which is called Unveiling (مكاشفة) or Witnessing (مشاهدة). This stems from His being possessed of sight (ذا بصر), for Allah described Himself as having sight, just as He described Himself as having knowledge. He said, <<أَنْزَلَهُ بِعِلْمِهِ>> (He sent it down with His knowledge) [Q. 4:166]. And in the Divine Hadith, He said to Moses and Aaron, <<إِنَّنِي مَعَكُمَا أَسْمَعُ وَأَرَى>> (Indeed, I am with you both; I hear and I see) [Q. 20:46]. And it is reported in the authentic Hadith of the Veils (حديث الحجب): "whatever His sight perceives of His creation." When He established the indication (الدلالة) of Himself, He established it in the horizons (الآفاق).

The signs of the horizons (آيات الآفاق) indicated His existence specifically. The horizons did not act as deputy in indicating Him by the signs placed within them, as man does, had He manifested to the world by His Essence. So, He created the Perfect Human (الإنسان الكامل) upon His Form (صورته) and established him as a proof of Himself for whoever wishes to know Him by the path of Witnessing (المشاهدة), not by the path of thought (الفكر), which is the path of seeing the signs in the horizons. This is His saying, <<سَنُرِيهِمْ آيَاتِنَا فِي الْآفَاقِ>> (We will show them Our signs in the horizons) [Q. 41:53]. Then, He was not satisfied with this definition until He referred to the Perfect Human, saying, <<وَفِي أَنْفُسِهِمْ>> (and within themselves). And here He said, <<حَتَّى يَتَبَيَّنَ لَهُمْ أَنَّهُ الْحَقُّ>> (until it becomes clear to them that it is the Truth). <<أَوَلَمْ يَكْفِ بِرَبِّكَ>> (Is it not sufficient concerning your Lord?) [Q. 41:53]—an allusion to the state upon which the Perfect Human was created, whom He established as the closest proof for knowledge through Unveiling (الكشف) and Witnessing (الشهود). The People of Witnessing said, "It is sufficient for us." <<أَلَمْ تَرَ إِلَى رَبِّكَ كَيْفَ مَدَّ الظِّلَّ>> (Have you not considered your Lord, how He extends the shadow?) [Q. 25:45]. He mentioned the 'how' (الكيف) and the shadow (الظل), and the shadow only emerges in the form of the one who extends it. So, He created him as Mercy, and He extended the shadow as a protective Mercy. No creature is greater in Mercy than the Perfect Human, and no creature is more severe in might and vengeance than the animalistic human (الإنسان الحيواني). Even if the Perfect Human strikes and possesses severe might, the animalistic human is more severe in might than him. For this reason, Abu Yazid said, "My might is more severe than His," referring to his animalistic self, because he strikes with what was not created, so there is no mercy in it, whereas the Real strikes those whom He created. Thus, Mercy is inherent in His might wherever it occurs. The prescribed punishments (الحدود) that He established in this world, wherever they are, are only for purification, as are pains, diseases, and everything that leads to them—all for purification, raising of ranks, and expiation of sins. When He created the Perfect Human and his successors among mankind upon the most complete Form, and there is no perfection except His Form,

He informed that Adam was created upon His Form.

...so that he might witness and know by the path of Witnessing. He concealed within his manifest form His Names (أسماءه) whose realities He bestowed upon him, and He described him with everything He described Himself with, and negated likeness from him. He is not likened, which is His saying, <<لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْءٌ>> (There is nothing like unto Him) [Q. 42:11] of the world—meaning, there is nothing like His likeness (مثل مثله) of the world. He was only a likeness by the Form. The angels objected to the emergence of Adam from nature (الطبيعة) because the Form carries contradictions, especially since Adam's existence was made from the elements. He is Divine, natural, and elemental. They did not witness the Divine Names, which are the rulings of this Form—namely, the Real being his hearing, his sight, and all his faculties. Had they witnessed that, they would not have objected. So, Allah disciplined them with what He mentioned. Then, the intellect (العقل) looked at the signs of the horizons and delved with its thought into those horizontal signs, witnessing transcendence (التنزيه) without the anthropomorphism (التشبيه) that the likeness granted by the Form implied. When the Real made the address heard—I mean, He made the intellect embedded in the animalistic human hear, not the Perfect Human, for the Perfect Human knew Him by himself—the animalistic human knew Him by his intellect after using the tool of his thought. The angel did not know the Perfect Human because he did not witness him in all his aspects, nor did the animalistic human know him by his intellect in all his aspects. Whenever a witnessing arose in his soul, without him realizing that it was the witnessing of the effect of the Real, he rejected it and declared the Real transcendent from it. If a Divine report came to him that conveyed what he considered a corrupt imagination, he interpreted that report in a way that led only to transcendence. Thus, he limited Him without realizing it, and he did not release Him. They all remained ignorant of the Perfect Human, and thus they were ignorant of the Real. None knew the Real except the Perfect Human. For this reason, the Prophets described Him with what they witnessed, and [the revelation] was sent down to them with the attributes of creatures, due to the existence of the perfection upon which the Real is. Neither an angel nor the intellect of an animalistic human reached this knowledge of Allah, for Allah veiled everyone from Him. He only manifested to the Perfect Human, who is His extended Shadow (ظله الممدود), His limited Throne (عرشه المحدود), and His intended House (بيته المقصود), described by the perfection of Existence. There is none more perfect than him, because there is none more perfect than the Real, glory be to Him. The Perfect Human knew Him from the perspective of his intellect and his witnessing, thus combining visual, unveiling knowledge (العلم البصري الكشفي) with intellectual, speculative knowledge (العلم العقلي الفكري). Whoever sees or knows the Perfect Human, who is the deputy of the Real, has known the one who appointed him as deputy and successor, for He manifested in his form. We were commanded to obey those in authority (أولي الأمر), just as we were commanded to obey Allah and His Messenger, and not to withdraw a hand from obedience, lest we die a death of ignorance (ميتة جاهلية). Ignorance is the worst thing for man. Had He, glory be to Him, not established the Perfect Human so that the knowledge of Allah, from the perspective of His being a God (إله) in contingent existence, could be realized as complete knowledge—which is the knowledge required of us—He would have manifested by Himself and His Essence to His creation so that they would know Him through witnessing and unveiling, and no one would deny Him. Those who deny Him in the Hereafter, or wherever the denial occurs, do so only because intellectual speculation preceded them, and they limited the Real. When they did not see the attributes by which they limited Him, they denied Him. Do you not see that when He discloses Himself to them with the sign by which they limited Him, they then affirm His Lordship? If He had disclosed Himself to them initially, before this limitation, none of His creation would have denied Him. For by His initial disclosure, He would be a proof of Himself. For this reason, we said that the Perfect Human is the deputy of the Real in manifesting to creation, so that the knowledge of Him may be achieved in the perfection required by the Divine Form. Allah, from the perspective of His Essence, is free from need of the worlds. The Perfect Human, by his existence and the perfection of his form, is free from the need for an indication of Him, because his existence is the very indication of Himself. Unveiling (الكشف) is the most complete of gnoses. Even if the Theophany (التجلي) is not repeated, the one who discloses Himself is one and known. Man knows himself that he turns over in his states, thoughts, acts, and secrets, all in different forms. Despite this turning and transformation, he knows his essence and his soul, and that his Ipseity (هويته) is the same, never changing, despite the transformation he undergoes. This is the nature of the Form of Theophany: even if the forms are numerous, the Theophany is not repeated, for the knowledge of the one who discloses Himself in these forms is one essence, not unknown. The transformations do not veil Him from him. This is the Fourth Vicegerency, which we have given its due. None knows what we have mentioned except one who is a bastard (زنيما) possessing wealth (مال), for by his form he entered into Divinity (الألوهة), yet he is not a God, so he was a bastard. And wealth necessitates richness (الغنى), so he possesses the attribute of richness by the form he is upon. Know that.

### [The Fifth Vicegerency is man's deputyship for the Exalter of Ranks in the World]

As for the Fifth Vicegerency (النيابة الخامسة), it is man's deputyship for the Exalter of Ranks (رفيع الدرجات) in the world, and nothing else. The nature of his exaltation is that the Perfect Human, from the perspective that no one shares his rank (درجته) because none other than him attained the Divine Form, his rank is exalted beyond reach. None knows him but Allah, and none knows Allah but the Perfect Human; he is His locus of manifestation (مجلاه). Since his rank was exalted by encompassing and attaining the totality (الكل), the part (الجزء) cannot know him, for the part has no knowledge of the whole, because a thing only knows itself and knows nothing except from itself, and the part does not possess the attribute of the whole. Thus, it is impossible for anyone to know the Perfect Human, because he does not possess the rank of the whole. The whole knows the whole like itself, and it knows what its totality encompasses of the parts, because they are like the limbs and faculties of its form, and a thing does not ignore itself. Thus, the totality of man manifested in a rank that cannot be reached. He acted as deputy, by what we mentioned that manifested in him, for the station of <<رَفِيعُ الدَّرَجَاتِ ذُو الْعَرْشِ>> (Exalter of [all] ranks, Possessor of the Throne) [Q. 40:15]. Man was thus a second existent (ثنى موجدة). His oneness (أحديته) accepted the second upon the form of his oneness. If you multiply the oneness of the Perfect Human by the oneness of the Real, only a single oneness emerges. You may then consider which oneness emerged and which oneness departed—the oneness of the deputy or the oneness of the one who appointed him. Act according to what manifests to you from that, and you will be happy. There is no ruling for the deputy that has an effect in the cosmos or a transcendence from likeness, except that ruling belongs to the one who appointed him. So, do not worry about which oneness manifested and which oneness was concealed, for His command is but one, as He said about Himself.

The matter is only thus,
The matter is only what was mentioned.

The saying is a decisive saying,
It has authority over mankind.

And the affair is a single affair,
In its essence, for the one who looks.

You are the Exalted, the Chosen,
With a Sovereign, Omnipotent King.

If you are of His Form,
Upon witnessing, then reflect.

What I have said, indeed,
Enters into the ruling of thought.

If you possess a sound intellect,
Safe from the other.

You will find it a clear truth,
In lines without forms.

The essence may witness it,
In forms and in lines.

And the Real is between them,
On His Throne, upon couches.

He confronts the likeness, just as
Forms confront forms.

So tell the one who knows Him
That he is in danger.

And tell the one who is ignorant of Him
That he is in delusion.

### [The Sixth Vicegerency is that Allah described Himself as having Words, so they multiplied]

As for the Sixth Vicegerency (النيابة السادسة), Allah described Himself as having Words (كلمات) which are numerous. Thus, there must be a separation (*al-Faṣl*) between the individual units of this multiplicity. Then, the single Word from Him is also multiplied in His saying: <<إِنَّمَا قَوْلُنَا لِشَيْءٍ إِذَا أَرَدْنَاهُ أَنْ نَقُولَ لَهُ كُنْ>> (Indeed, Our word to a thing, when We intend it, is only that We say to it, "Be!" [Kun]). He brought forth three letters: two manifest, which are the *Kaf* and the *Nun*, and one inner and hidden due to an incidental matter, which is the *sukūn* (vocalization pause) of the *Kaf* and the *Nun*. Its essence disappeared from the manifest due to the meeting of the two quiescent letters (التقاء الساكنين).

So, the Perfect Human (الإنسان الكامل) acts as the deputy in this rank (المرتبة) for the Real (الحق) in separating the preceding Word from the one that follows it. Thus, the Glorified One speaks in this human existence (النشأة الإنسانية)—and everyone who appears in its form—with the letters in the outlets of the breath (مخارج النفس) from this form. The existence of the letter in every outlet is its formation (تكوينه) if it was not already formed there; otherwise, who would form it? The Former (المكون) must necessarily be between every two words or two letters in order to bring the second word or the second letter into existence, and for the first to be connected to it. This is necessary in the Divine Words (الكلمات الإلهية) which are the Fixed Entities (الأعيان الثابتة) of the existent things, just as He said concerning Jesus (peace be upon him) that he is <<كَلِمَتُهُ أَلْقَاهَا إِلَى مَرْيَمَ>> (His Word which He cast unto Mary), and He said concerning her: <<وَصَدَّقَتْ بِكَلِمَاتِ رَبِّهَا>> (And she confirmed the Words of her Lord). And he (Jesus) is none other than Jesus, and He made him Words (كلمات) for her because he is multiple (كثير) from the perspective of his manifest and inner existence. Every part of him, whether manifest or inner, is a Word. Therefore, He said concerning her: <<وَصَدَّقَتْ بِكَلِمَاتِ رَبِّهَا>> because Jesus is the Spirit of Allah (روح الله) from the perspective of his totality, and from the perspective of the oneness (أحدية) of his multiplicity, he is His saying: <<وَكَلِمَتُهُ أَلْقَاهَا إِلَى مَرْيَمَ>> (And His Word which He cast unto Mary).

When the human speaks with letters, which are the parts of every word intended by the speaker—who is the human desiring the existence of those words so that what is in his soul may be understood through them, just as what is in the soul of the Real (نفس الحق) regarding the desire for the existence of the essences (أعيان) of what appeared was understood from Allah through the existent things that appeared—there must be precedence, subsequence, and arrangement in speech, just as that exists in the existent things, which are the essences (أعيان) of the Divine Words (الكلمات الإلهية). Precedence, subsequence, and arrangement are manifested by Time (الدهر), and Time is Allah, according to the explicit text, which is His saying (peace be upon him): "Do not curse Time, for Allah is Time."

In it (Time/Existence) appeared the arrangement, precedence, and subsequence in the existence of the World (العالم). Whether the speech is uttered or subsisting in the soul (النفس), if it is in the soul, the letters must exist within it in the existence of the Imagination (الخيال). If this is not the case, then it is not speech. This is the saying of the Arab poet:

> Indeed, speech is truly in the heart (الفؤاد),
> And the tongue is only made a guide to the heart.

He meant: a guide to what is in the heart. If the translator does not place the translation according to what is in the heart, based on the rule of correspondence (المطابقة), then it is not a guide. Multiplicity (الكثرة), precedence, and subsequence have been found in the translation, so the arrangement in the speech that is in the heart must be in this form, and this is nothing but the Imagination (الخيال) specifically. Allah the Exalted said: <<فَأَجِرْهُ حَتَّى يَسْمَعَ كَلَامَ اللَّهِ>> (Grant him protection until he hears the Word of Allah). He attributed the speech (الكلام) to Allah the Exalted and made it audible to the addressed Arab through his sense of hearing. He only perceived it as fragmented, preceding, and subsequent. Whoever does not attribute that speech, named the Quran, to Allah has denied what Allah revealed and is ignorant of the Realities (الحقائق).

Therefore, the deputy (النائب), when he speaks, must have the speech attributed to him as we have stated, and this deputy must separate between every two letters and two words by his essence (بذاته) so that the second may exist and the first may connect to it, until what he intends to manifest for the sake of the benefit (المصلحة) he knows is organized by it. Thus, he indicates what is in his soul through his speech. Not everyone who hears with his ear comprehends all or even some of what the speaker intended, except for the one whose insight (بصيرة) Allah illuminates. For this reason, the listener's share of the speaker's words may only be the arrangement of its letters, without comprehending what the speaker intended by what he spoke. This becomes apparent in the listener if the speaker addresses him in a language and dialect other than his own, for he understands nothing from it except what his hearing relates to him concerning the arrangement of its letters. This is the general connection (التعلق العام) for every listener. However, he does not know what these words were intended for. Similarly, the entire World (العالم كله) knows nothing of the existent things—which are the Words of Allah—except the existence of their essences (أعيانها) specifically. No one knows what these existent things were intended for except the People of Comprehension (أهل الفهم) from Allah. Comprehension (الفهم) is an affair beyond merely being audible.

Just as the speaking Perfect Servant (العبد الكامل الناطق) acts as deputy for Allah in bringing into existence what he speaks by separating His Words—for without his existence there, the existence of the essence (عين) of the Word and the letter would not be valid—likewise, he also acts as deputy in comprehension (الفهم) in that, taking the place of the Real (الحق) in His saying: <<وَلَنَبْلُوَنَّكُمْ حَتَّى نَعْلَمَ>> (And We will surely test you until We know). He described Himself as testing in order to know in the future. All of these are vicegerencies of Oneness (نيابة أحدية), not vicegerencies other than Oneness, in that they possess the Sustaining Power (القيومية) over the essences of existent things, based on the acquisition (الكسب) upon which the existent things subsist, for He is the One Who sustains <<عَلَى كُلِّ نَفْسٍ بِمَا كَسَبَتْ>> (over every soul with what it has acquired), and <<كُلُّ نَفْسٍ بِمَا كَسَبَتْ رَهِينَةٌ>> (Every soul, for what it has acquired, is held in pledge)—meaning, its acquisition is its restraint. Were it not for the Real (الحق), existent things would not be distinguished from one another, and the matter would be a single essence (عينا واحدا), as it is from another perspective. An example of this is that the human, from the perspective of his definition (حده) encompassing his individuals (آحاده), is a single essence (واحد العين). For all individuals are a single essence from the perspective of their humanity, even though we know that Zayd is not the essence of Amr, nor the essence of any other human individual. The essence of the Real's distinction (تمييز الحق) for them is their existence, and the essence of their distinction from one another belongs to their own souls (فلأنفسها). Therefore, the word of the Presence (كلمة الحضرة) did not add anything to the word *Kun* (Be!) in every existent thing; rather, the essence of *Kun* extended over every existent thing and nothing else. If we stopped at *Kun*, we would see nothing but a single essence. We only stopped at the effect of this Word, which are the things brought into existence (المكونات), so they multiplied, became numerous, and were distinguished by their individuals (أشخاصها). When they gathered in the essence of their definition (حدها), we knew that this Reality (الحقيقة) found the Word of the Real (كلمة الحق) within it, which is the word *Kun*. And *Kun* is an existential command (أمر وجودي) from which nothing is known except the act of bringing into existence (الإيجاد) and Existence (الوجود). Therefore, the existent thing is not told, "Be non-existent," nor is it told, "Be annihilated," because that is impossible. Non-existence (العدم) is essential (نفسي) for some existent things, and for others, it is dependent on the absence of the condition that validates its existence. By this Reality, Allah is eternally the Creator (خلاقاً دائماً) and eternally the Preserver (حافظاً دائماً). If it were as stated by those who oppose the People of the Real (أهل الحق)—those who claim the permanence of accidents (الأعراض)—it would not be valid for the Real to be eternally the Creator, nor the Preserver of the existence of some existent things. Since He never ceases to be eternally the Creator, He remains with every created thing: <<هُوَ مَعَكُمْ أَيْنَ مَا كُنْتُمْ>> (He is with you wherever you are). And "you are" (كنتم) is an existential matter without doubt. Nothing is more subtle than the vicegerency of separation between the Words (نيابة الفصل بين الكلمات) for one who knows what we have mentioned.

### The Seventh Vicegerency

As for the Seventh Vicegerency (النيابة السابعة), it is the vicegerency in the manifest and inner Acts (الأفعال) within the existence of the human, which is what he brings into being (يحدثه) within himself of acts and occurrences (الكوائن), not what he brings into being in others. Its sign from the Book of Allah is His saying, the Exalted: <<حَتَّى نَعْلَمَ>> (Until We know). Knowledge (*Al-’Ilm*) is an eternal Attribute (صفة قديمة) of His. This specific knowledge (العلم الخاص) that appears through testing (الابتلاء) is what He intends by the vicegerency here. So, the Exalted said about Himself that He answers the caller when he calls Him, and that <<بِيَدِهِ مَلَكُوتُ كُلِّ شَيْءٍ>> (In His Hand is the dominion [Malakūt] of all things). Thus, in this verse, He described Himself as the Subduer (قاهر) of all things.

If we claim patience regarding what He obligates us to do, and bear the hardship in that as obedience to Allah, and we call upon Him, then we look at the effect of that in our hearts, and we find that if the call encompasses our entire essence (ذاتنا) such that no part of us remains attentive to the other (الغير), the answer occurs immediately without delay. We know through this testing (الاختبار) the truthfulness of our turning toward Him, because we already know the truthfulness of what He informed about Himself. Were it not for observing Divine etiquette (الأدب الإلهي), our saying would be: "We tested Him with what we called upon Him for, until we knew His saying: <<أُجِيبُ دَعْوَةَ الدَّاعِ إِذَا دَعَانِ>> (I answer the call of the caller when he calls upon Me)." For this is a word of claim (دعوى) so that the vicegerency may be valid in His saying: <<وَلَنَبْلُوَنَّكُمْ حَتَّى نَعْلَمَ الْمُجَاهِدِينَ مِنْكُمْ وَالصَّابِرِينَ>> (And We will surely test you until We know the strivers [al-Mujāhidīn] among you and the patient ones [al-Ṣābirīn]).

Then we apply this to every claimant (مدع) of a claim, whether truthful or false. We act as deputy for the Glorified One in testing and trial (الابتلاء). If the claimant is truthful, like the Messengers and those who are truthful in their claim, he establishes the proof (الدلالة) of his truthfulness through what we tested him with by requesting the proof, whatever that proof may be. Similarly, we tested the liar when he claimed what was not his, and he failed to produce what we tested him with. So the deputy said to him: <<فَإِنَّ اللَّهَ يَأْتِي بِالشَّمْسِ مِنَ الْمَشْرِقِ فَأْتِ بِهَا مِنَ الْمَغْرِبِ>> (Indeed, Allah brings the sun from the east, so bring it from the west)—which is a possible matter—<<فَبُهِتَ الَّذِي كَفَرَ>> (And the one who disbelieved was dumbfounded), and the argument was established against him. The origin of the trial (الابتلاء) is the claim (الدعوى). Whoever has no claim has no trial directed toward him. This is why Allah did not obligate us until He said to us: <<أَلَسْتُ بِرَبِّكُمْ>> (Am I not your Lord?), and we said, "Yes." Thus, we affirmed His Lordship over us. Our affirmation of His Lordship over us is the very affirmation of our servitude (عبوديتنا) to Him. Servitude inherently demands obedience to the Master. When we claimed that, He then obligated us in order to test the truthfulness of what we claimed.

If you say: "What knowledge do we gain from this covenantal witnessing (الإشهاد الميثاقي) mentioned in the report? That is the share of faith (الإيمان), not the share of the intellect (العقل), and it is not a necessary matter. How then does the rational person (العاقل) who is not a believer enter into this trial?" We say: The rational person obligates himself by his intellect to glorify his Creator. The One Who obligates is Allah, because He is the One Who bestowed that intellect upon him. So the intellect stands for him in the place of the Messenger for us. The rational person looks with his intellect at his existence: upon what does it depend? Is he eternal in himself, or is he the one who brought himself into existence? Both matters are impossible for him. The discussion on this meaning has preceded in this book. Since that was impossible for him, he relied upon the Originator (موجد) of what is his essence. He then looked at what is appropriate for the One upon Whom he relies, and he purified Him (نزهه) from every description whose attribution to Him would lead to His origination (حدوثه). The reason for this is the strength of the soul, so that it does not worship its like—meaning, a contingent, originated thing like itself—for it knows its own origination. He saw by proof that He must be One, not multiple. He saw that similitude (المثلية) is negated from Him, and that He is upon a rank that necessitates glorification, praise, and commendation for Him. Thus, the intellect, which is in the position of the Messenger for us, obligated him to glorify His Presence (جنابه) with what He deserves, based on what the rational proofs (الأدلة العقلية) provided. So he began to praise Him, glorify Him, magnify Him, and purify Him (تنزيهه). He knew what Lordship (السيادة) deserves and treated it accordingly. Thus, he acted as deputy for the Real (الحق) in what he brought into existence within himself through his contemplation: gnosis (المعرفة) of Him and worship of his Originator, because he knew through his contemplation his own lowliness and neediness for a Manifestor (مظهر) far removed from the attributes that necessitate origination, in order for his essence to appear. Thus, every rational monotheist (عاقل موحد) enters into this vicegerency by his proof, even if he is not a believer. This is the saying of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) in the authentic Hadith: "Whoever dies while he *knows* (يعلم)—and he did not say 'says' or 'believes,' but mentioned knowledge specifically—while he knows that there is no god but Allah, he enters Paradise."

Every monotheist (موحد) of Allah will be admitted into Paradise by Allah specifically, and no one else. The believers and the Prophets intercede for the people of major sins (أهل الكبائر) among the People of Faith (أهل الإيمان), because the Prophets were sent with goodness, which is related to faith. The monotheists who did not believe—because no Messenger was sent to them, or they were in a period of intermission (فترة)—are those whom each one of them will be resurrected as a nation unto himself. If a Messenger was sent in a nation where he was present, and he did not believe in him despite his knowledge of the Oneness (أحدية) of his Creator, he enters the Fire. He will only be removed from it by his Creator, because eternal dwelling (الخلود) in the Fire is not decreed by text for the People of Monotheism (أهل التوحيد), regardless of how they attained it. Thus, no one remains in the Fire except a polytheist (مشرك) or an absolute denier (معطل) who did not arrive at that state through doubt or through a thorough, powerful contemplation. So, only the imitators (المقلدة) remain in the Fire—those who had the capacity and readiness to contemplate but did not. This is a matter of great benefit and sound origin. Its sign from the Quran is: <<وَمَنْ يَدْعُ مَعَ اللَّهِ إِلَهًا آخَرَ لَا بُرْهَانَ لَهُ بِهِ>> (And whoever invokes another god along with Allah, for which he has no proof)—meaning, in his own estimation that it is a proof, even if it is not a proof in reality. He has fulfilled his capacity, for Allah does not obligate <<نَفْسًا إِلَّا مَا آتَاهَا>> (a soul except with what He has given it). This is a matter in which people differ in degree. Then He said: <<فَإِنَّمَا حِسَابُهُ عِنْدَ رَبِّهِ>> (Then his reckoning is only with his Lord)—did he fulfill what Allah gave him of contemplation in that, or not? Then He said: <<إِنَّهُ لَا يُفْلِحُ الْكَافِرُونَ>> (Indeed, the disbelievers [al-Kāfirūn] will not succeed). And the disbeliever (الكافر) is only one who knew and then concealed (ستر). If he did not know, he is not a disbeliever. Then He commanded His Prophet to say: <<رَبِّ اغْفِرْ وَارْحَمْ>> (My Lord, forgive and have mercy) upon these groups who fulfilled the contemplation to the extent of the capacity He gave them, but only reached denial (التعطيل) or polytheism (الشرك), <<وَأَنْتَ خَيْرُ الرَّاحِمِينَ>> (And You are the best of the merciful). For they did not transgress what Allah gave them. Thus, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) intercedes for them here without their realizing it. When happiness reaches them by their exit from the Fire, and Allah has forgiven them through the Messenger's request for them, since He said: <<رَبِّ اغْفِرْ وَارْحَمْ>> when Allah commanded him to do so—and He only commanded him with this supplication to answer him—He answered him in that. They will then recognize the status of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) when they enter Paradise, and they will affiliate themselves with him therein because he is the Greatest Master (السيد الأكبر). This supplication encompasses everyone who is in this position, from the time of Adam until the blast of the Trumpet (نفخة الصعق), because He did not specify in His call anyone except those whose description is this, and who deserve to be shown mercy and forgiveness.

It is incumbent upon every deputy (نائب) among us to bring to mind these groups and everyone among the nations who has an excuse for falling short of the Real (الحق) as it is in reality, and to say: <<رَبِّ اغْفِرْ وَارْحَمْ وَأَنْتَ خَيْرُ الرَّاحِمِينَ>> (My Lord, forgive and have mercy, and You are the best of the merciful). For Allah the Exalted grants him a share in this intercession. So, O friend (ولي), do not neglect your share of it, and do not be among those upon whom dryness (اليبس) has prevailed, who restrict the Mercy of Allah (رحمة الله) to only affect the believer, and who do not distinguish between those who receive it necessarily (بطريق الوجوب) and those who receive it purely by Divine favor (عين المنة). This is an intercession from the Messenger and his deputies for these people in this world, which the Real establishes for them in the Hereafter without their knowing, until they enter Paradise. When they enter it, we will see in them the sign that grants us the acceptance of the worldly intercession (الشفاعة الدنيوية) concerning them.

It is incumbent upon every reciter (تال) when he recites the Quran to contemplate it and to take every command that Allah commanded His Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) to convey, or to say, or to know, and to say it in his recitation. He should not be merely narrating, but should be a person of intention (نية), purpose (قصد), and supplication (ابتهال) in that, and that he is commanded by the Real (الحق) to do so, if he wishes to be part of this Prophetic party (الحزب النبوي). For Allah concealed Prophethood (النبوة) in His creation and manifested it in some of His creation. The manifest Prophethood is that whose manifestation has ceased, but the inner Prophethood (الباطنة) remains in this world and the Hereafter, because the Divine Revelation (الوحي الإلهي) and the Lordly Sending Down (الإنزال الرباني) do not cease, since the preservation of the World (العالم) depends on it. The entire World has a share of this Sending Down and Revelation. Part of it is what He mentioned, such as His saying: <<وَأَوْحَى رَبُّكَ إِلَى النَّحْلِ>> (And your Lord inspired the bee), and <<وَقَالَتْ نَمْلَةٌ يَا أَيُّهَا النَّمْلُ>> (And a female ant said, "O ants"), and the hoopoe said to Solomon (peace be upon him): <<أَحَطْتُ بِمَا لَمْ تُحِطْ بِهِ>> (I have encompassed what you have not encompassed). The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said what he said concerning the jurists who strive (المجتهدين), and he did not stipulate correctness in everything they strove for; rather, he stipulated reward for them in that, whether they were correct or mistaken, and he differentiated between the correct and the mistaken in the reward. This is a strange vicegerency, lofty in rank, which not everyone knows.

### The Eighth Vicegerency

As for the Eighth Vicegerency (النيابة الثامنة), which pairs (شفعت) the singularity (*Witr*) of the Real (الحق) in that He is the locus of Theophany (مجلى) for it, and it is a locus of Theophany for Him. He looks at Himself in it with a gaze of perfection, and it looks at itself in Him with a gaze of perfection. This refers back to what the Real the Exalted is upon concerning the Divine Names (الأسماء الإلهية). This form does not appear except in the mirror of the Perfect Human (الإنسان الكامل), who is His Merciful Shadow (ظله الرحماني). He established a Throne (عرش) for him upon which He settled (استوى), in correspondence (على التقابل) with His Throne attributed to Him by the rule of settling upon it. Its example is what the Real described the people of Paradise with: <<مُتَّكِئِينَ ... عَلَى سُرُرٍ مُتَقَابِلِينَ>> (Reclining... on couches facing one another). That is, some face others. Reclining (*al-Ittikā’*) is reliance with the attribute of Omnipotence (الجبروت). So, the reliance of the Real upon him (the Perfect Human) is in what is manifest of the Real and hidden of the Perfect Human. For he (the Perfect Human) is elevated above his reclining place. The Perfect Human also reclines upon his Lord in what the human manifests of vicegerency when the Real is hidden within it. Thus, the witnessing (المشاهدة) and what is witnessed are attributed to the witness, not to another matter. Just as in the Presence of Acts (حضرة الأفعال), the act is attributed to the created being by custom (العوائد) while the Real is hidden within it, and the act that breaks custom (خرق العادة) is attributed to Allah, not to the created being, because it is outside the created being's capacity, so the Real appears—even though He only appears in the creation (الخلق).

The existence of the Real only pairs (ثنى) the creation because every reality (حقيقة) conceived for the Real cannot be conceived abstracted from the creation. Thus, it demands the creation by its essence. Therefore, the conceivability of Real and creation (حق وخلق) is necessary, because it is impossible for that Divine Reality (الحقيقة الإلهية) to have an effective relation (تعلق أثري) in the Essence (الذات) of the Real, and it is impossible for its ruling (الحكم) to remain suspended, because the ruling is intrinsic to it. Thus, the conceivability of creation is necessary, whether it is characterized by Existence or non-existence (العدم). For the establishment of its essence (ثبوت عينه) in non-existence is what makes it ready to accept effects (الآثار). Its establishment in non-existence is like the seed (البزرة) for the tree of existence. It is a seed in non-existence and a tree in Existence.

> The establishment of the essence in contingency is a seed (بزر),
> And were it not for the seed, there would be no plant.
> My manifestation from my establishment, without a Divine command,
> Is impossible when I was.

Since the matter is as we have mentioned, there is nothing in Knowledge (*Al-’Ilm*) but the pair (*al-Shaf’*), which is the doubling of the collection, because the Divine Realities (الحقائق الإلهية) are numerous, and the realized things (المحققات) are also commensurate with them. So the realized things doubled the Realities in Knowledge, even if they were not characterized by essential existence (الوجود العيني).

> Were it not for the establishment of the essence, it would not be witnessed,
> Nor would He say "Be!" to existence, nor would it be intended.
> The ruling of the essence has never ceased to be a worshipper of Allah,
> And the existence of the Real has never ceased to be worshipped by the essence.
> When the Real clothed it with the garment of its existence,
> Though it was lost in existence before the existence,
> The rulings were formed within it by its existence,
> So it never ceased to be prostrating, lost, and existent.

When the ruling of the doubling (تثنية) of the known matter appeared in itself, it was only valid through similitude (المثلية) and nothing else, because if it were not a likeness, He would not encompass it by His Essence, nor would it correspond to Him. And this is none other than the Perfect Human (الإنسان الكامل) or the totality of the World through the human. The human is indispensable, so let us restrict ourselves to him. The ruling of establishment (الثبوت) between Allah and the Perfect Human is different from the ruling of Existence (الوجود). By the ruling of Existence, the human is the one who doubles the existence of the Real. The ruling of establishment does not have this status, for the Real and the creation are together in establishment (الثبوت), but they are not together in Existence (الوجود). Since the matter in establishment is equal, we gave it the form of equilibrium (الاعتدال) and the absence of inclination toward either side. This is the lofty, widely known rank (المنزلة الرفيعة) with general effects. When the Real appears in forms, the equilibrium of similitude does not hold. The likeness is according to the form in which the Theophany (التجلي) occurs. If it is a spiritual form, what belongs to the rulings of spirits is attributed to it. If it is a corporeal form, what belongs to the rulings of manifest bodily forms is attributed to it, which is its characterization by natural descriptions such as changes of state in anger, pleasure, joy, descent, and hastening. If the Real establishes a matter for you concerning Himself, look at the form for which He established it, and judge it according to the ruling appropriate for that form. There is nothing there except a likeness or a non-likeness. We have fully covered the ruling of this Eighth Vicegerency.

### The Ninth Vicegerency

As for the Ninth Vicegerency (النيابة التاسعة), it is the manifestation in the intelligible Isthmus (البرزخ المعقول) that lies between the two likenesses (المثلين). It is the separation (*al-Faṣl*) that exists between the Real (الحق) and the Perfect Human (الإنسان الكامل). This separation necessitated the distinction of the Real from the creation (الخلق). One should look at which is more appropriate. Its position, in the analogy of the shadow, is the shadow attached to the person, relative to the extended shadow separated from him. The shadow subsisting in the person, between the person and the extended, separated shadow, is the Barzakh (البرزخ). It is more closely attached to the standing person, so it is more entitled to him. Thus, the distinction of the creation from the Real was by the Real, not the distinction of the Real from the creation by the creation. This is because the creation is clothed in the attributes of the Real, but the Real is not clothed in the creation. Therefore, the manifestation of the creation was by the Real, and the manifestation of the Real was not by the creation, because the Real has always been manifest to Himself, and thus was not characterized by neediness (الافتقار) in His manifestation for anything, unlike the creation which is characterized by neediness for the Real in the manifestation of its essence in its essence.

By creation (الخلق) here, we mean the human who possesses similitude (المثلية) and no other, for this separation occurred between the two likenesses. The ruling of the separation undoubtedly belongs to the two likenesses, because it corresponds to each likeness by its essence. Were it not for it, the likeness would not be distinguished from its like. Your similitude to Him is His saying: <<وَأَنْفِقُوا مِمَّا جَعَلَكُمْ مُسْتَخْلَفِينَ فِيهِ>> (And spend from that over which He has made you vicegerents [mustakhlafīn]), and His saying: <<وَهُوَ الَّذِي جَعَلَكُمْ خَلَائِفَ الْأَرْضِ وَرَفَعَ بَعْضَكُمْ فَوْقَ بَعْضٍ دَرَجَاتٍ ... لِيَتَّخِذَ بَعْضُهُمْ بَعْضًا سُخْرِيًّا>> (And He is the One Who made you vicegerents [khalā’if] of the earth and raised some of you above others in degrees... so that some of them may take others in service [sukhriyyā]). This is by granting the perfection of humanity—which is the Form (الصورة)—to some of them, who are those whom Allah raised. Those raised above are the animalistic humans. His similitude to you is that He made Himself your Agent (وكيلا) in what is rightfully yours, managing it on your behalf by the ruling of absolute, delegated, cyclical agency (الوكالة المطلقة المفوضة الدورية). The agency of the Real must be cyclical (دورية) out of Allah's care for His servant, because He created him prone to heedlessness (غفلات) and forgetfulness (نسيان). Heedlessness and forgetfulness are states that occur in this human existence (النشأة الإنسانية), and states have absolute ruling over everyone characterized by Existence; I exclude no existent thing from any existent thing. If the human is heedless in any of his movements and manages it himself, that self-management is an isolation of the Real from the agency. If the agency is cyclical, then whenever the Real is isolated from this agency by self-management, the Guardian (ولي الأمر) is not managing it—only Allah is managing it. For Allah commanded you to take Him as an Agent in Sūrat al-Muzzammil. This is the benefit of the cyclical agency. It is based on His command to His servant, and He placed it within Monotheism (التوحيد) when He said: <<رَبُّ الْمَشْرِقِ وَالْمَغْرِبِ لَا إِلَهَ إِلَّا هُوَ فَاتَّخِذْهُ وَكِيلًا>> (Lord of the East and the West; there is no god but Him, so take Him as an Agent). This is a reference to management in the directions, and He only mentioned the East (المشرق), which is the manifest, and the West (المغرب), which is the inner. By the single essence (العين الواحدة) which is the sun, when it rises, it creates the name of the East, and when it sets, it creates the name of the West. The human has a manifest and an inner aspect: <<لَا إِلَهَ إِلَّا هُوَ فَاتَّخِذْهُ وَكِيلًا>> (There is no god but Him, so take Him as an Agent) in your manifest and your inner aspects, for He is <<رَبُّ الْمَشْرِقِ وَالْمَغْرِبِ>> (Lord of the East and the West). Look at how wondrous the Quran is!

All these vicegerencies that we have mentioned and will mention are vicegerencies of Monotheism (توحيد) and nothing else. If you manifest, the manifest is none other than Him. If you do not manifest, He is He, since the One does not divide within Himself except by ruling and relation (الحكم والنسب). He the Exalted possesses many Names (أسماء كثيرة), so He possesses relations and rulings. His Oneness (أحديته) through us is the Oneness of Multiplicity (أحدية الكثرة), and the essence is one. Therefore, manifestation is attributed to us at one time and attributed to Him at another time, and it is attributed to Him in one ruling and attributed to us in another ruling. It has become clear to you that the essence in which the human subsists is the essence in which the Real subsists, between manifest and inner. When one manifests, the other is hidden. The vicegerency belongs to the manifest one on behalf of the one who is hidden, and the vicegerency belongs to the one who is hidden, in what he is hidden in, on behalf of the one who is manifest. The ruling of successorship (الخلافة) and agency (الوكالة)—which is successorship and vicegerency—is continuous and eternal, in this world and the Hereafter. For the Real, every day of the breaths (أيام الأنفاس), <<هُوَ فِي شَأْنٍ>> (He is in a state/affair) in which you have appointed Him as agent. He manages for you and directs for you in what He has made you His vicegerent over. Thus, you manage by the command of your Agent, so you are the vicegerent of your Vicegerent, just as He is the King of the King by agency. This is the very essence of what Existence (الوجود) is upon. There is no difference between us and the people in this matter in reality, except that I know, and they do not know, due to the coverings (الأغطية) over the eye of their insight (بصيرتهم) and the sheaths and locks (الأكنة والأقفال) upon their hearts, and within them.

### The Tenth Vicegerency

As for the Tenth Vicegerency (النيابة العاشرة), it is the vicegerency of the Monotheism of the Dead (توحيد الموتى). For by death, the coverings (الأغطية) are unveiled, and the Real (الحق) becomes clear to everyone. However, that unveiling (*Kashf*) at that time, generally speaking, only grants happiness to those among the common people who had prior knowledge of it. When the covering is unveiled and he sees as an essence (عينا) what he knew, he is happy. As for the People of Witnessing (أصحاب الشهود) here, it is an essence (عين) for them, and when the covering is unveiled, that essence becomes a Reality (حق) for them. Thus, the People of Unveiling (أهل الكشف) transition from the Essence to the Real, and the knowledgeable person (العالم) transitions from Knowledge (*Al-’Ilm*) to the Essence.
